greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table of k-fold factorials, read by antidiagonals.
link: G. C. Greubel, Antidiagonal rows n = 0..100, flattened
maple: seq(seq( mul(j*k+1, j=0..n-k-1), k=0..n), n=0..12); # _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020
mathematica: T[n_, k_]= Product[j*k+1, {j,0,n-1}]; Table[T[n-k,k], {n,0,12}, {k, 0, n}]//Flatten (* _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020 *)
program: for(n=0,12, for(k=0, n, print1(T(n-k, k), ", "))) \\ _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020
if k eq 0 or n eq 0 then return 1;
end if; return T; end function;
[T(n-k,k): k in [0..n], n in [0..12]]; // _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020
(Sage) [[ product(j*k+1 for j in (0..n-k-1)) for k in (0..n)] for n in (0..12)] # _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020
(GAP) Flat(List([0..12], n-> List([0..n], k-> Product([0..n-k-1], j-> j*k+1) ))); # _G. C. Greubel_, Mar 04 2020
results.author: _Philippe Deléham_, Jun 01 2015
